metadata.title: 'Certificated Operators' versus 'Handle-Turners': The British Film Industry's First Trade Union
metadata.journal_or_publisher: Journal of British Cinema and Television

relevance.topic: The history of the British film industry's first trade union and its impact on projectionists.
relevance.relevance: The study is relevant as it explores the historical context of labor displacement and the role of technological change in the British film industry, particularly focusing on the projectionists' trade union.

dependent_variables.displaced: Projectionists were displaced due to the transition from celluloid to digital projectors.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Projectionists faced unemployment and underemployment as their roles were downgraded.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Wages for projectionists decreased significantly as their roles were downgraded.

text_fragments: 'A form of skilled labour that has underpinned the very existence of cinema since its inception has been largely obliterated in the space of a few years, as digital projectors replaced their celluloid predecessors.'

'The vast majority of cinemas in the UK have taken advantage of certain opportunities provided by the digitalisation of projection - which simplifies or automates various key elements of this craft - to cut their salary costs by significantly downgrading the role and status of the projectionist and implementing wholesale redundancies.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a detailed historical account of the formation and activities of the National Association of Cinematograph Operators (NACO), highlighting the challenges faced by projectionists due to technological changes and the union's response to these challenges.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The period saw the transformation of cinema into a mass medium offering cheap entertainment, primarily for working-class audiences.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses the role of trade unions, specifically NACO, in the British film industry and their efforts to protect projectionists' rights.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that the National Association of Cinematograph Operators (NACO) was ineffective in addressing the challenges faced by projectionists due to technological changes and the transformation of the cinema industry.
outcomes.conclusions: NACO's efforts were inadequate in protecting projectionists from the exploitation and displacement caused by the transition to digital projection technology.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the displacement of projectionists due to technological changes had long-term impacts on their employment and wages.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study relies on historical analysis, which may not capture all aspects of the technological and labor changes.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent narrative of the historical context and the role of NACO in the British film industry.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses a rich set of historical data to support its findings.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is relevant to understanding the historical context of labor displacement due to technological change in the film industry.
